sv:property.sv:value: For mosts projects simply just replace bootstrap.css file (in /btk/webresources/css/) to apply your own styles. And with provided templates like home / article page, section component for grid, or components like text & image, teaser, link / button, image with popup, youtube video and few others, your project development goes much faster.

Bootstrap is so far most used framework today, especially for bigger projects for which you probably choosing Magnolia too. And it's 12 column grid can be nicely implemented with Magnolia, but luckily you don't have to think about how, because BTK has it already implemented.

If your project (html prototype from your designer) is based on Bootstrap framework, then this light module is the best place to start from. It contains all basic components such as text & image, image with modal, links / buttons and teaser, carousel, youtube video, jumbotron and html. Other then these components it also contains section component - this is a master component for rows and columns (grid) logic.

But not only components, this light module also contains home and article page templates with main area, inherited footer area and autogenerated navigation and breadcrumb areas.

These all are purely made for Bootstrap framework, but there is also few more templates which shows some every day functionalities, such as search and search results, content app list and detail rendering, etc.
BTK is your project starting point!

Its completely up to you. Sometimes you may need just reuse set of components, sometimes you may completely use it as your project foundation and start adding more templates into it. or completely customize it. 

Also many things are configurable over yaml files, such as default class names for components, type of container on page or section grid layout options.

Maybe you may just spend a little bit of time looking at code and see some best practices for developing with Magnolia.

BTK is a basic set of templates which are build following the best practices for pages made with Bootstrap framework (www.getbootstrap.com). And its ideal for starting new Magnolia project which requires to use Bootstrap.

"My name is Tomáš Gregovský and I hope this module can help you to save some time while developing Bootstrap based projects same as it does for me on many projects I was working past year. I would be glad if you can tweet some words how did you find it with hastag #btk_magnolia or/and @magnolia_cms. Thank you!"

twitter.com/GregovskyT
* This demo site is fully made with BTW without any else customization.
'BTK' integrates Bootstrap Framework into Magnolia and offers set of basic components which supports this very popular front end framework.
'BTK' integrates Bootstrap Framework (http://getbootstrap.com/) into Magnolia and offers set of basic components which supports this very popular front end framework.

For example section component handle width of its inner columns using Bootstrap's class names for columns e.g. 'col-lg-6'. Images usually have 'img-responsive' class name and over their dialog is easy to apply additional class names like 'img-circle' or others. Same for link component which can be just over dialog change to button with one of predefined styles such as 'btn-primary', 'btn-success', etc...

Lets have a deeper look on all definitions of BTK light module:
col-xs-12 col-sm-6 col-md-4, col-xs-12 col-sm-6 col-md-4, col-xs-12 col-sm-6 col-md-4

• home + article
  • search page (using searchfn)
  • content app page (list + detail rendering)
  • navigation (using navfn)

• section/row component 
  • text & image, image, teaser, link, html, carousel, youtube video, jumbotorn
  • search component (searchfn), contacts (list and detail of content app data)

• navigation (with or without navfn) for page links, content app links, search input
  • list (area component listing, each component know about it position in list e.g. count, total, even/odd, has next, ...)
  • breadcrumb

Every component from BTK has extra 'styles' tab in dialog. This tab is usually used to change html of component to apply different Bootstrap styles (class names). For example in text and image component title size can be defined (h1 > h6), same as image style which will apply specific class names to image such as 'circle', 'rounded' or 'thumbnail' (see screenshot on right). 

Similar dropdown exists for link component where you may choose from link vs button styles ('btn-link', 'btn-success', ...) same as button size ('btn-lg',...).

All of these can be easily edited, or decorated to add more options which are interesting for your project.

And for more experience editors there is a 'additional DIV class' field in every component same as on every page, using which you can easily add another class name to current object. No matter if something project specific, or something from Bootstrap, e.g. 'text-center' (to have all text centered).

Because Bootstrap framework contains iconic font 'glyphicons' it would be pity not to implement it as well. So components such a text & image, teaser or link / button, contains dropdown with all glyphicons options (don't forget first choose 'Icon from Glyphicons' in 'Image or Icon' option).
BTK is easily customizable just editing template definitions (yaml), dialogs (yaml) or html (ftl). Same as using Sass (scss) to modify and recompile styles.

If you already have prototypes from your graphic designer, just replace /btk/webresources/css/bootstrap.css file, or drop all of them to /btk/webresources/css/ - resfn will loads all of them on page.

If you don't, use SCSS - edit source files in /btk/webresources-sources/scss and recompile them with gulp, grunt or any else building tool, maybe with simple node-sass (you may find how to install and recompile with node-sass in README.md file of BTK light module).

Or for quick test, generate resources online on http://getbootstrap.com/customize/ and again, just replace /btk/webresources/css/bootstrap.css file.

Resources templating functions - resfn in /btk/templates/pages/home.ftl will also loads all css and js files automatically just when you drop them into /btk/webresources/css/ or /btk/webresources/js/ folders.

There is a lot you can define / customize in templates definitions.

For example in every page definition you can define body and navbar class name, main and navbar container type. (see screenshot on right)

Each component has his parent class name as a property in yaml definition. Usually its just name like 'btkTextImage' which is not really used by bootstrap, but some other has combination of this with bootstrap specific, for example carousel -  'btkCarousel carousel slide'. So nothing is easier then decorate or edit directly these yaml files.

Grid layout - options for width of columns in row (section), are defined directly in section component dialog. (see screenshot on right).

By default there is few layout options already preconfigured but its so easy to add as many others just folowing Bootsprap's grid's paterns.

In BTK templates, most of areas has custom templateScript (/btk/templates/areas/list.ftl) to render components in area (see screenshot on right). This is updated script to render list of components in area and other ten regular rendering it give each component information about total number of components in list, which of them is current component, if its odd/even and if has next. 

This data can then be used in each component over ctx object, e.g.: '${ctx.parity}'

Since Magnolia 5.5.2 we have navigation templating functions - navfn which is quite handy and flexible to build custom navigations of many forms.

In /btk/templates/areas/navigationWithNavfn.ftl you can see how with navfn you can list all subpages and then render regular navigation links, content app dropdown or search field based based on page template.

What is missing in code but its tipicaly also heavily used is instead of checking for template ( navfn.hasTemplate() ) is to check for depth and render different html structure for each depth.

And its easy to use navfn just to generate links, for example with selectors, in any template independently fom navigation itself (check /btk/templates/components/search.ftl or /btk/templates/components/contacts.ftl for navfn.linkWithSelector() ).

In case of older Magnolia without navfn there is a /btk/templates/areas/navigation.ftl which does similar more old-school way.

Search component (templateScript: /btk/templates/components/search.ftl) is an example how to use search templating functions - serchfn to search in website or any else workspace.

Nice example you cna see in navigation which renders input field instead of link to page (if page template is 'btk:pages/search'). This is an easy way how to have search on page without defining where search result page is.
... are ideal way how to work with indexed data. As a basic example let's talk abou contacts.

... are ideal way how to work with indexed data. As a basic example let's use ootb contacts app, but its so easy to edit code and change ti to any your custom content app.

Both list and detail rendering is defined in one file: /btk/templates/components/contacts.ftl - feel free to check. Dropdown in navigation is done in /btk/templates/areas/navigationWithNavfn.ftl

And BTW did you know that with Content Types module installed you can define new workspace directly from light module. And apps definitions are supported in light modules since beginning, nothing stops you to do content apps fully light module.
